meanings.definition: To express deep sorrow or grief over.
meanings.sent1: She would bewail the loss of her favorite toy for days.
meanings.sent2: The villagers would bewail the destruction caused by the storm.
meanings.sent3: The puppy would bewail the empty food bowl in a dramatic fashion.
meanings.sent4: The old tree seemed to bewail the loss of its leaves in the autumn wind.
meanings.sent5: The haunting melody made her bewail the memories of her childhood.

meanings.sent1: He would bewail the passing of his beloved pet with tears in his eyes.
meanings.sent2: The poet would bewail the state of the world in his verses.
meanings.sent3: The child would bewail the end of the weekend, dreading the start of school.
meanings.sent4: The widow would bewail her loneliness in the quiet of the night.
meanings.sent5: The howling wind seemed to bewail the desolation of the abandoned house.
